section-block.rac_essential-question: What do we do at school?

section-block.rac_book_caption: Big Book: Ming Goes to School

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Deirdre Sullivan Illustrated by Maja Löfdahl
section-block.rac_book_summary: Ming is ready for her first day at school and for all the days after. She finds out that school is a great place for learning, making friends, and having fun!

section-block.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Use Cc and Dd Alphabet Cards.
section-block.rac_body-text: C is for cat. I spy a cat. Who can show me what I spy? Continue for both sides of the cards.
Invite children to join as you sing “This Is the Way We Go to School,” and together mime the actions in each verse (getting dressed, brushing teeth, riding the bus).

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Ming Goes to School, written by Deirdre Sullivan, and illustrated by Maja Löfdahl. How many words are in this title? Let’s clap each word. How many words?
Pablo loves when we read with him. Ming Goes to School is one of Pablo’s favorite narratives. He loves how the pictures help tell the story.
I have a question I want you to keep in mind while we read. After we read, we will try to answer it together. Ready?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What does Ming do at school?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: It’s the first day of school for Ming. Who does she say “hello” to?
Ming meets new friends in school. She brings her stuffed toy to school and introduces him to her new friends. What would you bring to school to show your friends? (MB)
Ming builds fairy castles. I see the letter C in the word castle. Who can point to that letter?
Oh, look! Who do Ming and her friends pretend to be when she is walking the plank? Who do you like to be when you pretend?
What is Ming doing now that she has been waiting to do all year? Why do you think she is ready now?
Let’s turn and talk about the Guiding Question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What does Ming do at school?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Using Equity Sticks, choose two or three pairs of children to share their responses.
Possible responses:
Write and read aloud short sentences about school rules as children watch and listen.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does Ming meet new friends at school?
Ming meets new fr________ (friends) at school.
Ming meets new friends at school.
What do you like to pretend when you play dress up?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: When you read, always stop to engage children in looking for picture clues. In this book, the classroom window is an excellent item to use to teach the skill. As you read, ask children to notice how it changes. Guide children to see that these pictures tell the story of the changing seasons. Children will love seeking out the clues.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder:Play With Others
section-block.rac_body-text: Point out that Ming is learning to play with the other children at school. Sometimes you might want to join a group of children who are playing. You might say, “Can I play, too?” Sometimes you might start to play and want someone to play with you. What would you say if you wanted someone to pretend with you? (MB)

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to think about the Mind Builder and see how Ming plays with others. Let’s read Ming Goes to School by Deirdre Sullivan.
Clifford is excited to read a story about a girl who plays with her friends at school.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builders
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions.
Read aloud the book and the Day 2 prompts.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Ming joins the children who are building train tracks. What do you think she said to the other children when she sat down to play? (MB)
Ming is waiting and watching the other children on the climbing bars and on the slide. What do you think she is waiting for?
Ming and her friend are playing in the snow in winter. What do you think Ming said when she wanted her friend to play in the snow?
Look at the picture. Ming wrote “Please come to tea.” Ming pretends to have a tea party. Why is writing a note about the tea party a good idea? Do you see the letter C on Ming’s note? (MB)
The children are decorating the window with signs of spring. What would someone say if they wanted to join the group and make some spring flowers? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Play “Row, Row, Row, Your Boat.” Give Connecting Cubes to half the children. Ask children to march around the room as you sing the song. When you stop singing, ask each child with a cube to hand it to another child and say, “Will you play with me?” When two partners find each other, ask them to sit. When all the children have partners, have them pretend to row a boat as they sing “Row, Row, Row, Your Boat.” Now have children holding the cubes begin the activity again.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about playing with children at school.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children progress from parallel play (playing next to each other), to associative play, and then to creative play. Playing with others is an important Mind Builder skill that leads to increased conversations, growth in vocabulary, and self regulation. (Singer, ed., 2006)

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_3: Share the Social Studies Skill: Connect Ideas
section-block.rac_body-text: Choose an activity Ming does and have children describe how they do the same one at their own school.
Invite children to join as you sing new lyrics to “This Is the Way We Go to School,” miming the actions as they do so (draw at school, build at school, dance at school).

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the book Ming Goes to School by Deirdre Sullivan.
Pablo is excited to reread Ming Goes to School. He likes to read narratives about children having fun at school.
Keep in mind this question as we reread today:
Which activities do you think Ming does every day at school?

section.rac_body-text: An important Social Studies skill for children is to connect their own lives to events, time, and routines. Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Have conversations with children as they make connections to their own school routines.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do you think Ming and friends bring things to share every day? What rules do you think they should have for showing and sharing time at school? (MB)
Think about when we rest in class. How are the friends in the picture resting? Why is resting something Ming does every day at school?
Ming is hosting a tea party. What other things do you think Ming pretends to be when she dresses up every day at school?
Ming squirms in the mud. Think about how a worm squirms. How does it move? Show me how you can squirm.
What clues can you find in the pictures that tell you what Ming and her friends are making?
Let’s turn and talk about the Guiding Question: Which activities do you think Ming does every day at school?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.Then, use Equity Sticks to choose two or three children to share their thoughts.
Possible answers:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: She plays dress up and pretends.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to write about school, inviting children to write about favorite activities.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does Ming pretend every day at school?
Ming pr_______ (pretends) every day at school.
Ming pretends every day at school.
What are some things Ming might do when she plays outside?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: When vocabulary words are hard to translate directly, the Act It Out feature on each card can make it easier, and more fun, to learn challenging words. Allow multilingual children to share translations for each word in their own languages to create a diverse classroom.

section-block.rac_body-text: Lead a discussion about the rules children follow in their classroom. For example: “What is a good rule to follow when we want to answer a question in school?” (MB)
Place a teddy bear on a chair. Ask children to pretend it is a new preK friend. Invite children to take turns telling what kind thing they would do to make the new friend happy.
Introduce two new words that will be helpful to the continued conversation about rules.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read “Our School Rules.” It is a poster with informational text.
Pablo likes posters because they make informational text so easy to understand!
Ming Goes to School and “Our School Rules” each show what children do at school.
As we read the Big Chart, let’s talk about the concept question for the week:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What do we do at school?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart. Use the prompts to read and discuss the pictures.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Where do we follow school rules?
What are these friends sharing? How do you ask friends to share toys at school? (MB)
Can you find the word we? Clean? Up?
What is the boy doing to help clean up? How do you help clean up at school? (MB)
Who can point to the letter C in the word clean?
Why is it good for these children to take turns? How do you take turns with friends? (MB)
The children are listening to their teacher. Why is it important to listen at school? (MB)
Who is it that helps these children stay safe? (MB)
How is one boy kind? (MB)
Remember Ming? What kind thing do you think Ming would do?

section.rac_body-text: Remind children that when they play a game, it is important to follow rules. Invite children to play “Duck, Duck, Goose.” Review the rules before play begins.
Provide a writing prompt asking about how children share at school. Give ongoing feedback as children draw and write.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Connecting content from different texts leads children to look more deeply into each, and possibly glean new understandings. This is helpful when texts of different genres are used, such as narratives and informational texts. Connecting the poster to the book brings a sense of realism to Ming’s story, while providing more detailed examples of following rules.

section-block.rac_body-text: In the book, Ming pretends she is a pirate walking the plank, and a princess hosting a tea party. Invite children to pretend to be something and ask others to guess. Demonstrate how to give clues through actions and words. For example, move like a robot and say in a robotic voice, “I have many buttons to push.”

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we’re going to reread the narrative Ming Goes to School by Deirdre Sullivan. We will also reenact, or act out, some of the things we see in the beautiful pictures by Maja Löfdahl.
Pablo loves narratives that are made up stories—like this one.
You’ve had time to think about this book, and we’re going to share some of your thoughts today. As we reread the story, think about this Guiding Question:
How is your school day like Ming’s school day?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the Big Book together. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Ming’s dad drops her off for her first day of school. Then she waves good-bye to him. Show me how you would wave good-bye.
Ming likes to play with trains and tracks. Let’s pretend Ming wants to join in when friends are playing. Tell her what to say to them.

Sometimes it’s fun to think about favorites. Let’s vote to see which you like better—a toy soldier or a stuffed animal. Put your hands on your head if you like the toy soldier. Put your hands on your head if you like the stuffed animal.
section.rac_body-text: Explain the process as you go along. Count children and see which toy got more votes.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What did Ming make with sticks and dirt? Let’s pretend we are making castles. What can we use?
Why is Ming giggling? Pretend you are laughing with Ming. Show me how you giggle.
Let’s pretend it’s rest time in our school. Show me how you rest.

section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk about the Guiding Question:
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How is your school day like Ming’s?
section.rac_body-text: Using Equity Sticks, pick two or three children to share their ideas.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: I play with trains and tracks.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about their school day, or Ming’s, and share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What activities does Ming do outside? What activities do you do outside?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Being part of a group and recognizing that rules are important for the group is valuable to learn in preK. As children progress through the year, help them make group decisions by setting up a process of voting. Voting can be done by showing hands, counting chips or cubes, or making a graph with sticky notes.
